CreditLine: Bequest of Mrs. Jean M. Riddell, 2010
Description:
The Danish-born, Empress Maria Feodorovna, wife of Alexander III, presented this kovsh to a Danish medical doctor, Jens Schon. 

This vessel resembles a duck with its stylized, angular tail serving as the handle. The decoration is composed of tendrils and fruit in pastel colors over a cream ground. Cabochon amethysts serve both for the bird's eyes and as additional decoration on the handle.
Dimensions: H: 4 1/2 x W with handle and nose: 6 3/8 x D: 2 13/16 in. (11.5 x 16.2 x 7.2 cm)

Geographies.GeoHierarchy: The Thesaurus of Geographic Names\World\continents\Asia\nations\Rossiya\republics\Rossiya\autonomous cities\Moskva\inhabited places\

Inscriptions: [Marks] In Cyrillic with Imperial warrant: POvchinnikov, kokoshnik right, delta, 84, circular kokoshnik; [Inscription] Engraved in Danish: Fra Kejserinde Maria Feodorowna til professor, dr. med, Jens Schon 2 Febr 1910
Medium: silver gilding, painted filigree enamel, amethysts
Provenance: Empress Maria Feodorovna [date and mode of acquisition unknown]; Dr. Jens Schon, February 2, 1910, by gift; Jean M. Riddell, Washington, D.C. [date and mode of acquisition unknown]; Walters Art Museum, 2010, by bequest.
Title: Bird-shaped Kovsh
